repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Yemen - Land and Water
            Conservation, Taiz Water Supply Pilot, and Sana'a Water
            Supply and Sanitation Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The report rates the three projects as
            such: The Land and Water Conservation Project had a
            satisfactory outcome, is likely to be sustainable, has a
            modest institutional development impact, and satisfactory
            performances by both the Borrower and the Bank. The Taiz
            Water Supply Pilot Project had an unsatisfactory outcome, is
            unlikely to be sustainable, has a modest institutional
            development impact, and unsatisfactory performances by both
            the Borrower and the Bank. The Sana'a Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project had a moderately satisfactory outcome, is
            unlikely to be sustainable, has a high institutional
            development impact, unsatisfactory performance by the Bank,
            and satisfactory performance by the Borrower. The report
            cites four key lessons for success, which were not
            emphasized enough to affect the outcomes in two of these
            three projects: 1) identifying and tackling the dominant
            issue-here, the depletion of Yemen's water resources;
            2) having a comprehensive strategy based on sector analysis
            and a program approach; 3) having cross-sector planning and
            coordination among the rural, urban, and other water
            water-using sectors; and 4) developing rural-urban water markets.

repnme.cdata!: Yemen - Land and Water Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact modest. Lessons reinforce that: 1) the
            timing in water resources management should not be too
            ambitious, specifying that the leverage achievable under a
            single operation, of limited size, should not be
            overestimated, if driving for reforms in a crucial subject
            such as water policy; 2) project design, and implementation
            arrangements should be kept simple, exemplified by the
            coordination among a number of departments, and
            institutions, including regional agricultural offices.
            Despite initial coordination difficulties at the central
            level, the decentralized implementation mechanisms of the
            project, assumed by the various Project Implementation
            Units, and coordination at the local level, proved to be
            successful; 3) more efforts are needed to ensure adequate
            funding of recurrent costs; thus, the Bank should raise this
            issue in its dialogue with the Ministry of Finance, and the
            Ministry of Planning, in a concerted manner, and beyond the
            level of individual projects; 4) cost sharing targets, and
            upper limits on the size of farms, need to be realistic.
            Initially, the project envisaged full cost recovery for
            irrigation equipment, and prescribed a maximum size of
            benefiting farms; however, no farm met these conditions. To
            this end, the farm size was modified, and farmers'
            contributions to cost-sharing reduced, a pragmatism that
            allowed implementation, without abandoning the principles of
            cost sharing; and, 5) basin planning should be piloted,
            given the limited capacity of implementing agencies;
            actually, pilot basin planning should be introduced in an
            area under favorable conditions, and demonstrated ability of
            local users, to then engage in collective efforts.

18154799.admreg: Middle East and North Africa,Middle East and North Africa
18154799.theme: Water resource management,Land administration and management,Environmental policies and institutions,Biodiversity

repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Yemen - Land and Water
            Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the project are to
            strengthen sustainable agriculture through:  (i)
            institutional and technical developments in irrigation and
            forestry; (ii) initiating a program of water resource
            monitoring and regulation in the agriculture sector; (iii)
            improving water use efficiency in irrigated agriculture;
            (iv) conserving key indigenous forest areas, accelerating
            tree planting, and extending soil and water conservation;
            and (v) establishing approaches for watershed management and
            terrace stabilization. The project provides:  (a) improved
            groundwater irrigation conveyance systems for about 14,350
            ha; (b) equipment to demonstrate improved irrigation
            application technologies; (c) materials for constructing
            improved structures for spate irrigated schemes on
            identified wadis; (d) equipment and vehicles for irrigation
            systems maintenance, and for strengthening the water
            monitoring system; (e) materials and equipment for forest
            nurseries, sand fixation and flood control activities, and
            for watershed management and terrace stabilization; and (f)
            construction of offices, and provision of vehicles,
            equipment, training and technical assistance for the Water
            Resources Sector and the Directorate General for Forestry
            and Rangelands of the Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources.
